entries.meaning: (now archaic) Someone who romps; especially, a girl or young woman who indulges in boisterous play; a tomboy. [from 17th c.]
A period of boisterous play, a frolic; now especially, a bout of sexual activity, especially when illicit. [from 18th c.]
An enjoyable, fast-paced but essentially inconsequential film, play, or other piece of entertainment. [from 19th c.]
(chiefly sports) A decisive victory; a game, match etc. which is won easily. [from 20th c.]

verbs.description: romp (third-person singular simple present romps, present participle romping, simple past and past participle romped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To play about roughly, energetically or boisterously.
(transitive, US) (Often used with down) To press forcefully, to encourage vehemently, to oppress.

examples: Ronald Koeman collected that prize in the run-up to this game, and then watched his team romp to their biggest victory for nearly a century, inflicting a defeat that Sunderland will struggle to forget.

entries.meaning: (with adverb) To move with little effort relatively quickly.
examples: We romped along with the wind astern.

entries.meaning: (slang) To engage in playful or boisterous sex.
